Introduction

Impetigo is a superficial skin infection that typically occurs in children; it presents with honey-crusted papules and pustules on the face and extremities.  The most common causes are Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes, and management is antimicrobial therapy.

Risk Factors



  • Age:  most common in children age 2-5
  • Preexisting skin trauma/inflammation:  wounds (eg, cuts, insect bites), infection (eg, herpes simplex virus [HSV]), or inflammation (eg, eczema, burn)
  • Climate:  more prevalent in warm, humid regions
  • Poor hygiene:  increases the likelihood of bacterial colonization

Pathophysiology



Impetigo is an infection of the superficial epidermis most commonly caused by bacterial invasion through a break in the skin barrier, including infection (eg, HSV, varicella virus, scabies), inflammation (eg, eczema, burn), or any open wound (eg, cuts, insect bites).  Less commonly, impetigo can be caused by primary infection of previously intact skin.



The most common pathogen responsible for impetigo is S aureus, followed by S pyogenes (group A Streptococcus [GAS]).  Whereas either bacterium can cause nonbullous impetigo (papules and pustules with honey-colored adherent crusting), S aureus alone is responsible for bullous impetigo.



The blistering in bullous impetigo is caused by the production of exfoliative toxin A, a serine protease that targets desmoglein 1 in the superficial epidermis, by certain strains of S aureus.  Desmoglein is a cadherin component of desmosomes found in epidermal cellular junctions; disruption by exfoliative toxin A causes loss of cell adhesion and leads to the formation of flaccid bullae.

Clinical presentation



Variants include nonbullous impetigo (more common) and bullous impetigo.



Nonbullous impetigo presents with the following (

image 1
):



  • Erythematous papules and pustules that coalesce and rupture, leading to a classic honey-colored, adherent crusting or weeping
  • Self-inoculation to nearby sites, which is common
  • Involvement of the face/extremities


Bullous impetigo causes the following (

image 2
):



  • Enlarging vesicles, which progress into flaccid bullae filled with yellow fluid.  The lesions rupture, leaving a classic collaret of scale at the periphery of the lesion.
  • Ruptured lesions, which may develop an overlying crust, although they often lack the classic honey-colored coating of nonbullous impetigo.
  • Involvement of intertriginous areas and the trunk/extremities.


In both forms, lesions may be mildly tender or pruritic, and mucus membranes are not affected.  Localized lymphadenopathy can occur, and fever is usually absent but can be seen with the bullous variant.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of impetigo is usually clinical based on classic findings of yellow-crusted papules and pustules (nonbullous impetigo) or ruptured and crusted bullae with a collarette of scale (bullous impetigo).



Gram stain and bacterial culture may be obtained to identify the pathogen (eg, S aureus, S pyogenes).

Differential diagnosis



  • HSV infection:  Symptoms include recurrent, painful clusters of mucocutaneous vesicles that evolve into ulcerated and crusted lesions.  It typically causes localized perioral or genital lesions; involvement of the fingers (eg, herpetic whitlow) can occur.  Perioral HSV (
    image 3
    ) typically involves the vermilion border, and HSV lesions do not spread.
  • Atopic dermatitis:  Findings in infants and young children include erythematous papules and plaques involving the head, trunk, and extensor surfaces.  In older children and adults, lichenification in a flexural distribution (
    image 4
    ) (eg, neck, wrists, antecubital and popliteal fossae) is typical.  Affected areas appear erythematous and dry when inflamed; yellow crusting is suggestive of infection and would not be seen with isolated eczema.
  • Eczema herpeticum (
    image 5
    ):  HSV infection of eczematous skin presents with vesicles overlying eczema patches and can become disseminated.  Lesions are painful and progress to punched-out erosions with hemorrhagic crust.  Neither flaccid bullae nor honey-colored crusting is typical.
  • Contact dermatitis:  A delayed hypersensitivity reaction can occur after use of a new product (eg, lip balm) and may cause pruritic, erythematous vesicles with clear fluid.  Honey-colored crust would not be expected, and local spread does not occur.
  • Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (
    image 6
    ):  Manifestations include oral lesions plus a bilateral, nontender, nonpruritic maculopapular and/or vesicular rash of the palms and soles.
  • Autoimmune disease:  Bullous pemphigoid (
    image 7
    ) is associated with antibodies against hemidesmosomes and is characterized by tense, subepidermal blisters.  Pemphigus vulgaris (
    image 8
    ) is characterized by intraepithelial cleavage and is due to autoantibodies against desmosomes; it presents with flaccid bullae, desquamation, and oral ulcerations.  Both disorders cause scattered or widespread lesions and are uncommon in children.
  • Shingles (
    image 9
    ):  Shingles most commonly occurs in adults and is caused by varicella-zoster virus.  It presents with painful vesicles and bullae in a dermatomal distribution.

Management



Although impetigo is a self-limited infection (typically over 2 weeks), antibiotics are indicated in all patients to reduce recovery time and transmission (including autoinoculation to distant sites):



  • Topical antibiotics (eg, mupirocin) are adequate for localized, nonbullous impetigo (and preferred over oral antibiotics due to fewer adverse effects and decreased risk for antibiotic resistance).
  • Oral antibiotics (eg, cephalexin, dicloxacillin) are warranted for widespread nonbullous impetigo (which makes topical therapy impractical) and all cases of bullous impetigo.


Because impetigo is contagious, hand hygiene and coverage of actively draining lesions are also important for preventing spread.



Lesions typically resolve without scarring or long-term sequelae.

Complications



A rare complication of GAS impetigo is acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN).  Kidney damage is caused by immune complex deposition and subsequent complement activation (

figure 1
), precipitating an inflammatory response 1-3 weeks after the initial infection that damages the glomerular basement membrane.  Treatment of impetigo does not prevent the development of APSGN.



The presentation of APSGN ranges from asymptomatic, microscopic hematuria to overt nephritic syndrome; pyuria and nephritic-range (<3.5 g/day) proteinuria are common.  In addition to tea- or cola-colored urine, symptomatic patients can develop periorbital/facial swelling, generalized edema, and hypertension.  Laboratory evaluation typically shows elevated creatinine and decreased C3 levels.

Summary



Impetigo (
